en_second_half: was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. es_first_half: Y, después de presumir así de mi tolerancia, me veo obligado a admitir que tiene un límite. Me da lo mismo, superado cierto punto, que la conducta se funde sobre piedra o sobre terreno pantanoso. Cuando volví del Este el otoño pasado, era consciente de que deseaba un mundo en uniforme militar, en una especie de vigilancia moral permanente; no deseaba más excursiones desenfrenadas y con derecho a privilegiados atisbos del corazón humano. La única excepción fue Gatsby, el hombre que da título a este libro: Gatsby, que representaba todo aquello por lo que siento auténtico desprecio. Si la personalidad es una serie ininterrumpida de gestos logrados, entonces había en Gatsby algo magnífico,
es_second_half: una exacerbada sensibilidad para las promesas de la vida, como si estuviera conectado a una de esas máquinas complejísimas que registran terremotos a quince mil kilómetros de distancia. Tal sensibilidad no tiene nada que ver con esa sensiblería fofa a la que dignificamos con el nombre de «temperamento creativo»: era un don extraordinario para la esperanza, una disponibilidad romántica como nunca he conocido en nadie y como probablemente no volveré a encontrar. No: Gatsby, al final, resultó ser como es debido. Fue lo que lo devoraba, el polvo viciado que dejaban sus sueños, lo que por un tiempo acabó con mi interés por los pesares inútiles y los entusiasmos insignificantes de los seres humanos.

en_second_half: sundials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run. en_results_raw: a narrow stream that flowed into the bay. The sound of the water was soothing, and the smell of saltwater filled the air as I stepped out of my car and onto the driveway. As I walked towards the house, I couldn't help but notice the perfectly manicured lawn, the vibrant flowers that lined the walkway, and the large trees that towered above, their leaves rustling in the gentle breeze. The front door, adorned with a large brass knocker in the shape of a lion's head, swung open as I approached, and my friends, Tom and Daisy, stood in the doorway, beaming with smiles, eager to greet me. They welcomed me with open arms, and we exchanged warm hugs, the tension of not having seen each other in years, slowly dissipating as we stepped inside. The interior of the house was just as impressive as the exterior, with high ceilings, large windows, and beautifully decorated rooms, each one filled with expensive-looking furniture and artwork. We made our way to the living room, where a fire was crackling in the fireplace, casting a warm glow over the room, and the sound of jazz music floated through the air, adding to the relaxed atmosphere. As we sat down, Tom offered me a drink, and we spent the next hour catching up on old times, sharing stories, and laughter, the warmth and hospitality of my friends, making me feel like I was home.

en_results_raw: dingy, cramped conditions of the dwellings that line the riverbank. The air is thick with the smell of decay and neglect, and the only signs of life are the scrawny chickens pecking at the dirt and the listless children playing in the shadows of the crumbling buildings. The trains rumble and screech as they wait for the bridge to lower, spewing out passengers who stretch their legs and gaze out at the desolate landscape. Some of them take a deep breath, as if hoping to catch a whiff of something better on the wind, but all they get is the stench of rot and stagnation. The valley of ashes seems to stretch on forever, a barren and unforgiving place where hope goes to die.

en_first_half: It was nine o’clock—almost immediately afterward I looked at my watch and found it was ten. Mr. McKee was asleep on a chair with his fists clenched in his
en_second_half: lap, like a photograph of a man of action. Taking out my handkerchief I wiped from his cheek the spot of dried lather that had worried me all the afternoon.
en_results: lap. I was sitting on the edge of the bed, staring at him, and I couldn't help but feel a mix of emotions. There was a sense of relief that the tension had momentarily
en_results_raw: lap. I was sitting on the edge of the bed, staring at him, and I couldn't help but feel a mix of emotions. There was a sense of relief that the tension had momentarily dissipated, but at the same time, I was anxious about what the future held. The silence in the room was palpable, broken only by the sound of Mr. McKee's gentle snores. I glanced around the room, taking in the familiar surroundings, but my mind was elsewhere. I thought about the events that had led us to this point, and I couldn't help but wonder what the next day would bring. As I sat there, lost in thought, I felt a sense of unease creeping over me. It was as if I was waiting for something to happen, but I wasn't quite sure what it was. The minutes ticked by at a glacial pace, and I found myself checking my watch every few seconds, willing the hands to move faster. And then, just as I was starting to feel like I couldn't take the silence anymore, Mr. McKee stirred. He opened his eyes, looked around the room, and then fixed his gaze on me. For a moment, we just stared at each other, the only sound the quiet hum of the clock on the mantle. Then, without a word, Mr. McKee slowly got to his feet, his movements stiff from having slept in the chair. He stretched his arms over his head, arching his back, and let out a low groan. I watched him, my heart pounding in my chest, as he made his way over to the window. He pulled back the curtain, and a sliver of moonlight streamed into the room, casting an ethereal glow over everything. Mr. McKee stood there for a moment, staring out into the night, and I could sense a deep sadness emanating from him. I wanted to go to him, to comfort him, but something held me back. Maybe it was the uncertainty of the situation, or maybe it was something more. Whatever it was, I remained frozen, watching as Mr. McKee slowly turned away from the window, and began to make his way back over to the chair. As he sat back down, he looked up at me, and our eyes met once again. This time, however, there was something different in his gaze. It was a sense of determination, of resolve. And in that moment, I knew that everything was about to change.

Sin embargo, una noche, un joven llamado Juan, que había oído las historias sobre el traficante, decidió investigar por su cuenta. Se acercó a la tienda del traficante, que estaba cerrada, pero Juan logró entrar a través de una ventana. Dentro, encontró una gran cantidad de licores de todos los tipos y tamaños, pero también encontró algo que lo hizo sentir un escalofrío: un cuaderno con nombres y direcciones de personas que, al parecer, habían sido víctimas del traficante. en_second_half: ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
en_results: strand of her hair that had come loose and was being gently blown across his cheek by the breeze. I remember thinking that it was a very romantic scene, the kind that would make a great shot for a movie. And then,

I remember thinking that it was a very romantic scene, the kind that would make a great shot for a movie. And then, suddenly, everything went black. When I came to, I was lying on the ground, my head throbbing with pain. I tried to sit up, but a wave of dizziness washed over me and I fell back down. I heard footsteps approaching and then a voice, faintly calling out my name. I tried to respond, but my voice was barely a whisper. The voice grew louder and closer, until I felt a hand on my shoulder, shaking me gently. I opened my eyes to find Daisy's face hovering above me, her eyes wide with concern. "What happened?" I tried to ask, but my voice was still barely audible. Daisy helped me sit up, and I looked around, trying to get my bearings. We were still in the garden, but the party was over. The music had stopped, and the guests were all gone. The only sound was the distant hum of crickets and the soft rustling of leaves in the breeze. I looked up at Daisy, who was still holding my hand, and asked again, "What happened?" This time my voice was a little stronger, and Daisy's expression turned serious. "You fainted," she said. "I think it was the heat. You've been out for a few minutes." I nodded, still trying to clear my head. I looked around again, taking in the empty garden, and then my eyes landed on something that made my heart skip a beat. The moving-picture director and his Star were still there, standing under the white-plum tree, their faces still touching. But this time, they were not alone. There was someone else with them, someone I hadn't noticed before. A woman with long, curly brown hair and a white dress that seemed to glow in the fading light. She was standing just behind the director, her eyes fixed intently on him. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that I had seen her before. She was the woman from my dreams, the one who had been haunting me for weeks. I tried to speak, to ask Daisy who she was, but my voice caught in my throat. The woman's eyes flicked towards me, and I felt a jolt of electricity run through my body. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything went black again.

I listened intently, trying to understand the depth of his emotions, and the complexity of his relationship with Daisy. As he spoke, I couldn't help but feel a sense of melancholy wash over me, a sense of loss and regret that seemed to permeate every word he uttered. His eyes would glaze off into the distance, lost in thought, as if he was reliving moments from their past, moments that he cherished deeply. I could sense the weight of his grief, the weight of his love, and I knew that he was struggling to come to terms with the fact that she was truly gone.

They stood there for a moment, the only sound being the soft rustling of the leaves and the distant hum of a car driving by. The night air was filled with a sense of possibility, and the two figures walking together seemed to be the only people in the world. They turned a corner, and the street opened up into a wide boulevard, lined with trees and filled with the sound of laughter and music. They walked on, lost in their own little world, as the night stretched out before them like an endless sea of possibilities.

I felt a rush of exhilaration, the thrill of the unknown, as the speedometer climbed higher and higher. Tom's eyes were fixed on the road ahead, his jaw set in a determined line, as he pushed the car to its limits. I felt a sense of freedom, of release, as the world whizzed by in a colorful haze. The engine roared, the tires screeched, and I laughed out loud, feeling alive, feeling free. The countryside gave way to a small town, and Tom slowed, expertly navigating the narrow streets, before accelerating again, the car surging forward like a wild animal unleashed. I felt my heart pounding in my chest, my senses on high alert, as we devoured the road, the wind whipping my hair into a frenzy. And then, suddenly, Tom slammed on the brakes, and we skidded to a stop, the tires smoking, the engine sputtering. I looked at Tom, my heart still racing, and saw a slow grin spreading across his face. "What's wrong?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper. Tom's grin grew wider, and he leaned in close, his voice low and husky. "We're here," he said, his eyes glinting with mischief. "Where's here?" I asked, my curiosity piqued. Tom just chuckled, and nodded towards the trees. I followed his gaze, and my eyes widened in surprise. We were at the edge of a dense forest, the trees towering above us, their branches creaking ominously in the wind. I felt a shiver run down my spine, as Tom turned off the engine, and the silence was oppressive, heavy with anticipation. What were we doing here? And why?

After all, I had to get away from the East, from the memories that lingered in every corner, every street, every whisper of the wind. The Midwest, with its vast plains and rolling hills, seemed like a place where I could escape, where I could find some peace. I had to get away from the jazz, the champagne, the extravagant parties, and the endless stream of people who seemed to be always in a hurry. I had to get away from the green light across the water, the elusive dream that Gatsby had chased, and I had chased with him. The Midwest, with its simplicity, its quietness, and its familiarity, seemed like a place where I could find myself again, where I could rediscover the person I was before I got caught up in the whirlwind of Gatsby's world. I had to go back to my roots, to the place where I grew up, to the place where my family was from. I had to go back to the Midwest, to the place that I had left behind, to the place that I had forgotten. And so, I packed my bags, said goodbye to the East, and headed west, towards the sunset, towards the place that I called home.

İçeri girdim ve salonun ortasındaki büyük masaüstünde, Gatsby'nin bir zamanlar bana gösterdiği o eski fotoğraf albümün durduğunu gördüm. Albümün sayfalarını çevirdikçe, Gatsby'nin Daisy ile olan ilişkisinin, benim için taşıdığı anlamı daha iyi anladım. O an, Gatsby'nin hayaletinin, East Egg'deki evinin önünden, bana doğru yükseldiğini hissettim.
